poem:
At the Venice Biennale

In the hushed Arsenale
ghosts of ships gather,
wooden ribs creak beneath
modern feet,
Chekhov whispers through 
ancient beams.

Dancers weave shadows,
voices escape over sea,
past the edge of night,
running from the reach
of borders.

Imagination ignites—
flickering like lanterns 
on a long-lost 
deck.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Venice Biennale theatre: running from UK immigration and revisiting Chekhov The Venice Biennale is always associated with big exhibitions. But there is also a strong programme of dance, currently run by Wayne McGregor, and of theatre, now in its 52nd edition. In the case of theatre, 15 shows are packed into two hectic weeks in June with all the events taking place in the Arsenale: the vast naval shipyards that in the 17th century turned". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
